title: Inside sheltered housing with mould, rotting doors and exposed electrics
text:

Shocking pictures show the "diabolical" state of sheltered housing which has prompted pensioners to consider withholding their rent.

Holes in the ceiling, rotting doors, mouldy window frames, exposed electrics and threadbare carpet tiles have sparked anger.

Residents in Walwyn Gardens in Bristol have revealed a catalogue of problems with their block, Bristol Live reports .

Most people inside the 27 flats said they have issues in their individual homes, but the communal areas of the block have caused the most concern.

In the main entrance, a huge crack scars a wall. In the community room, the carpet doesn’t completely cover the floor, revealing dirty and rotten wooden boards underneath.

(Image: BristolLive/ WS)

(Image: BristolLive/ WS)

In the toilet and kitchen area wires are exposed and not boxed in, and optimistically, someone has long ago written ‘Blocked here’ with an arrow pointing at a dirty, decaying and ageing pipe.

The corners of the windows are bug-ridden and paint-peeled, holes patched up by faded sticky tape.

But in the ceiling, one tenant points to the worst issue. A scar emerges from the end of the window and widens as it moves across the top of the room, the ceiling plaster long gone, exposing the rotten wood above.

“I just don’t think it’s safe at all,” said Glenis Chard.

“I won’t go in there really. When it rains, the water pours through, and there’s electrics in that ceiling, there’s wires - it’s dangerous,” she added.

(Image: BristolLive/ WS)

(Image: BristolLive/ WS)

"The carpet is threadbare, falling to pieces. You've got a lot of people living in here who don't walk so well and it's just a shocking trip hazard, for starters."

Mrs Chard said that more than a year ago, the two wardens that manage Walwyn Gardens told residents that things were going to be sorted, and that Bristol City Council had agreed it was time for a refurbishment, a major repair job.

“They told us it would be sorted,” said Mrs Chard.

“In February this year, all these surveyors came around with cameras, measuring up, taking pictures of what needed doing. We were all hopeful,” she explained.

(Image: BristolLive/ WS)

“And then, nothing. We were told the plans were in place, but then that it was on hold. It’s got worse in that time,” she added.

Parts of this area in Bristol were recently named as statistically one of the most deprived places in Britain.

The plight of the residents of Walwyn Gardens comes as a Bristol Live investigation revealed people in Hartcliffe who said they feel forgotten and left behind, both nationally and by the rest of the city.

(Image: BristolLive/ WS)

(Image: BristolLive/ WS)

(Image: BristolLive/ WS)

“It’s not right that we should be paying our full rent to live in this building, when we can’t use the facilities - if it carries on any longer, we’ll all start thinking about withholding some of our rent, seeing as though where we live is in this state,” she said.

“This is diabolical,” she said.

Bristol City Council is yet to provide an explanation about the state of Walwyn Gardens.
description: Pensioners in Bristol have experienced holes in the ceiling, mouldy window frames, and threadbare carpet tiles
